sections.heading: Minimum Quantity Lubrication Turning of Titanium Alloy by using Evolutionary

sections.text:
Munish Kumar Gupta1, P.K. Sood2, Vishal S Sharma3
1,2MED, NIT, Hamirpur (H.P.), INDIA 3I & P Deptt., Dr. B.R. Ambedkar NIT Jalandhar, Punjab, India Address correspondence to Munish Kumar Gupta, MED NIT, Hamirpur (H.P.)-177005, India, munishguptanit@gmail.com, +919855162229
Abstract: In metal cutting operations, the proper selection of machining parameters and cutting fluids affects the cutting mechanism, which is associated to the cutting forces, tool wear, cutting temperature and surface finish of the machined part. For this purpose, the effect of cutting fluid types is investigated as a function of three machining parameters (cutting speed, feed rate and approach angle) on responses (cutting force, cutting temperature, tool wear and surface roughness) while turning titanium alloy under Nano-Fluid based Minimum Quantity Lubrication (NFMQL) environment. The experiments are conducted based on response surface methodology and a combined objective function using the output parameters was generated. Further, the parametric optimization was performed through two evolutionary techniques, i.e., Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Bacterial Foraging Optimization (BFO). The results are analyzed and also compared with the traditional desirability function approach technique.
Keywords: Machining; Optimization; PSO; BFO; NFMQL.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, titanium based alloys such as Ti (grade-2) are finding immense application in various industries like turbine and aircraft manufacturing because of their admirable properties like high corrosion resistance and strength at exalted temperatures. But still, they are considered as materials with poor machinability because of high toughness and low heat transfer coefficient (Singh and Sharma, 2016). The major concerns in machining of these alloys are to attain good surface finish and high quality tolerances along with the reduced cost of manufacturing. So as to achieve this requirement, it is necessary to raise the cutting speed, tool life and decrease the quantity of scrap (Da Silva et al., 2013; Deiab et al., 2014; Gupta et al., 2015).
Even though, the several factors can affects the machining of titanium alloys, still the application of cutting fluids is considered as one of the prominent factor (Gupta et al., 2015). The cutting fluid represents a considerable proportion of the total costs of production. In the United States (period from 1994 to 1999), Independent Lubricant Manufacturers Association (ILMA) accounted that, the 95 to 103 million gallons of cutting fluids were formed on a yearly premise (NIOSH, 2001). In the 2005 year, it has been reported that nearly 38 Mt of lubricants were consumed worldwide, with an estimated increment of 1.2% over the next decade (Kline and Company, 2006). Other reports indicate that nearly 320,000 Ton/Year of metal working fluids (MWFs) is consumed by European Union alone, of which, at least two-thirds need to be disposed (Abdalla et al., 2007). This rapidly increasing consumption of MWFs caused numerous negative effects on the environment and posed significant health hazards (Davoodi, 2014). In order to ease the economic and environmental impacts, some sustainable and environmental friendly techniques namely dry machining, minimum quantity lubrication (MQL) and cooling with nano-fluids are found to be an alternative and showing better results as compared to conventional techniques (Sharma and Sidhu, 2014; Ghosh and Rao, 2016; Ghosh and Rao, 2015).
Dry machining is the machining which completely removes the consumption of MWFs. However, high temperatures during dry machining are not suitable for titanium based alloys and can cause the lesser tool life along with the poor surface quality (Huang et al., 2014). Therefore, the MQL is another sustainable method introduced to overcome the limitations of dry machining. MQL has shown significant results in machining technologies so far (Hadad and Sadeghi, 2013). In MQL technique, cutting oil particles in mist form is delivered to the cutting zone (tool-work

interface) by compressed gas. The minuscule quantity of coolant is not only less waste polluted, but also subjected to several other ecological and biological advantages: reduction in the quantity of coolant used as well as can save time and money for the chip recycling purpose (Singh and Sharma, 2016; Gupta et al., 2015; Sharma et al., 2015). The research efforts on application of MQL technique has been continuously reported and the majority of reports proved it to be a proficient method as contrast with other methods (Hasib et al., 2010; Sadeghi et al. 2010; Barczak et al., 2012; Sharma et al., 2015; Sharma and Sidhu, 2014). The MQL technique with nano-particles (nano-fluids) also contributes in green or cleaner manufacturing, as the harmful effects of other MWFs are completely eliminated from the machining process.
Nano-fluids refer to cutting fluids obtained by dispersing the certain amount of nano-particles (average sizes < 100 nm) in base fluids. When the little amount of nano sized particles are consistently suspended and dispersed in base fluids, can give overstated upgrades in the thermal characteristics of base fluids (Das et al., 2008). The various types of nano-particles such as Al2O3, graphite, diamond, boric and MoS2 with excellent properties are frequently employed to improve the thermal conductivity and lubricity of coolants (Samuel et al., 2011; Park et al., 2011; Khanderkar et al., 2012; Vasu and Reddy, 2011). Samuel et al. (2011) dispersed the graphene in semi-synthetic metal-working fluids (MWFs) for micro-turning operation and reported it to be more effective as well as efficient as compared to conventional MWFs. Similarly, Park et al. (2011) discussed the effect of nano-graphene based MQL in ball milling operation. For these investigations, firstly the nano based MQL lubricant was examined for the tribological properties. The results seem that nano-graphene based MQL provides lesser tool wear as contrast to dry and flood cooling. In yet another scientific study, Vasu and Reddy (2011) studied the impact of Al2O3 nanoparticles with MQL in turning of Inconel 600 alloy. They conclude that there is considerable lessening in tool wear, temperature dissipation, cutting forces and surface roughness while using Al2O3 nano-particle with MQL. Khandekar et al. (2012) brought out the beneficial effect of Al2O3 nano-particles in conventional cutting fluids while turning AISI 4340 steel. Likewise, Paul and Varadarajan (2013) evaluate the performance of MQL with grease and graphite nano-particles while turning AISI 4340 steel. The outcomes demonstrated that the utilization of grease and graphite with MQL helps to lessen the cutting forces, tool vibrations, cutting temperature, surface finish as well as tool wear. Sharma et al. (2015) examined the turning of AISI D2 Steel (surface roughness and cutting temperature) by employing CNT with MQL method. The results indicated that the CNT with MQL shows quite auspicious results over using conventional cutting fluid.
It is manifest from the open literature that, the use of nano particles with MQL in machining has proved to be an effective method. However, the type of nano-particles used along with the proper machining parameters governs the success of the NFMQL turning process in the context of cost and productivity. In order to achieve the aforementioned goals, an optimum selection of the machining process parameters is required to be identified. In the last few years, various traditional optimization methods (like Taguchi, Response surface method etc.) have been successfully implemented around the globe in various fields of machining (Gupta et al., 2015; Kumar and Chauhan, 2015; Gupta et al., 2016). However, these traditional methods may provide a local optimization solution resulting in reduced accuracy and non-robustness. Apart from these, some evolutionary techniques, namely PSO, Genetic

Algorithm (GA), Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) and BFO etc. have been successfully implemented in different fields of engineering (Mukherjee et al., 2006; Rao, 2011). Most of these algorithms may not achieve the global optimal results in the context of parametric optimization of manufacturing processes. Among these algorithms, PSO and BFO are very easy to implement and provide very compromising as well as accurate results. Also, the information sharing mechanisms of these techniques are significantly different from the other techniques. For example, in GAs, the whole cluster or group shifts toward an optimum solution, whereas in PSO only the local best or global best solution are shifts towards the idle solution, thereby the fast convergence takes place (Karpat and Ozel, 2007; Gupta et al., 2015). However in the case of BFO, the major steps like chemotaxis, swarming, reproduction, elimination and dispersal are used to update the bacterium position. Recently, BFO technique is effectively used to resolve numerous real world issues namely harmonic estimation (Mishra, 2005), transmission loss reduction (Tripathy, 2006), active power filter for load compensation (Mishra and Bhende, 2007), power network (Tripathy and Mishra, 2007), load forecasting (Ulagammai et al., 2007) and stock market prediction (Majhi et al., 2007).
A sufficient amount of research articles have been available on these evolutionary techniques in the parameter optimization of manufacturing processes. But, to the best of our knowledge, till date, the research efforts on the application of PSO and BFO in the field of NFMQL turning of titanium (grade-2) alloy have not yet been made. Due to these aforementioned reasons, this study represents the first attempt to investigate the optimization of machining parameters and cutting fluids while turning titanium (grade-2) alloy considering NFMQL conditions by using two evolutionary techniques i.e., PSO and BFO.
The remaining paper is organized in a lucid manner. In materials and methods section, the details of workpiece materials, cutting inserts, NFMQL system, measurement devices are elaborated. The effect of process parameters on given responses, ANOVA test, the optimization methods and confirmatory tests are investigated in the results and discussion section. Finally, the concluding remark of this paper is discussed in the conclusion section.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of nano-fluids
sections.text:
The nano-fluids were prepared by two step methods. The three different types of nano-particles i.e., aluminium oxide (Al2O3), molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) and graphite having average diameter of 40 nm were used. The vegetable oil was chosen as base oils due to their good biodegradability and low environmental impact. The concentrations of nano-particles in vegetable base oils were 3 wt%. The concentration was ultra-sonicated in a sonicator (40 kHz, 100 W) (for 1 hour) and magnetic stirrer (30 minute) as shown in Fig. 1. The process was repeated several times until all the nano-particles dispersed consistently in the vegetable base oil. The results indicated that the nano-fluid prepared was steady and no settlement of particles was found throughout the entire machining operation. The properties of nano-fluids were measured and shown in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.3. Turning tests
sections.text:
Turning was performed on a BATLIBOI Sprint 20TC model CNC with a spindle motor of 11 kw and spindle speeds in the range of 30-4000 rpm as shown in Fig. 2. For NFMQL system, the compressed air (flow rate of 60 l/min) from reciprocating compressor (input air pressure of 5 bars) together with cutting fluid (lubricant flow rate of 30 ml/hr) was hybridized in the set of nozzles and delivered spray onto the tool-chip interface.
Fig. 2. Experimental Setup

sections.heading: 2.4. Measurements
sections.text: The cutting force measurements were made using the TeLC DKM2010 dynamometer associated with XKM software, whereas the HTC make infrared thermometer was used to record the temperature at tool-chip interface. The flank wear was measured using the Mitutoyo’s make tool maker’s microscope, while the surface roughness (arithmetic average, Ra) measurements was conducted with the assistance of Mitutoyo SJ 301 surface roughness tester. In each test, three surface roughness measures at three different points of the finished workpiece in the tool movement direction were taken to reduce the experimental errors. In the end, the machined surface of titanium (grade-2) alloy was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Bruker make).

sections.heading: 2.5. Experimental design
sections.text:
In this work, the cutting speed, feed rate, approach angle and cutting fluids were considered as the primary factors, whereas the depth of cut 1 mm was kept constant. Then, the experiments were planned and executed with BoxBehnken design (BBDs) using Response Surface Methodology (RSM). A total of twenty nine experiments were carried out, as tabulated in Table 3. The proposed methodology was divided into three stages. Firstly, the effect of each parameters on given response was studied by perturbation graphs using RSM. After that a combined objective was formed and analyzed using analysis of variance (ANOVA) test. Then, the optimization of combined objective was performed with the help of desirability function approach. In the second stage, the two evolutionary techniques, namely PSO and BFO were employed to determine the optimal factor. At the end of work, the developed models were verified and compared with the confirmatory experiments.
Table 3. Experimental design and their results

sections.heading: 2.7. PSO

It was initially introduced by Eberhart and Kennedy (1995). It combines the characteristics of both evolution strategies (ES) and generic algorithms (GA). It easily takes care of continuous optimization problems unlike the generic algorithms. The basic concept of this technique lies in the examination of the movements of a group of natural creatures like birds and reconfiguring the created model into a computer. These groups of creatures or birds often behave like a swarm. Thus, the movement of each agent or creature inside a swarm may be modelled using simple vectors. These flocks of birds (also called intelligent agents or particles) are set across the search space in a random way and several iterations are conducted for these randomly moving particles. Each particle updates its current location during iteration with a certain velocity on the basis of pbest i.e. the best searched position of that particle and gbest i.e. the best particle position in the entire population. Originally introduced by Passino in 2002, BFO is nature inspired numerical optimization technique that is influenced by food searching behavior of motile bacteria such as E. Coli and Salmonella. The bacteria search for nutrients and avoid noxious substances in search space by propelling themselves with the aid of locomotive flagella. Depending upon the clockwise or anti-clockwise rotation of flagella, the bacteria either tumble chaotically or move in systematic manner (swim or run) respectively to locate for better gradient of nutrients. The frequency of tumbling or swimming of bacteria depends upon nutrient concentration of search space i.e. in better nutrient concentration; the bacteria will tend to swim more than tumble in random direction. The motion patterns engendered by bacteria in the form of tumble or swim for foraging nutrient food is known as chemotaxis. sections.heading: 3. Results and discussions
sections.text: Table 3 depicts the outcomes obtained after the experimentation. Firstly, the effect of process parameters on selected responses were investigated with the help of perturbation plots. Then, the combined objective was established. Afterward, the significance and adequacy tests were commenced using ANOVA. In the end, the optimization on combined objective was performed with desirability function approach, PSO and BFO.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of process parameter on responses
sections.text:
Cutting forces: Fig. 3 (a) depicts that, the ascending trend of cutting speeds as well as feed rates, both results the high cutting forces. This might be occur because the rise in cutting speed along with the feed rate extends the toolchip contact length, thus high cutting forces were produced. It is also observed that for Ti (grade-2) alloy, the approach angle shows very less effect. The major reason is that, the approach angle only assists to improve the removal of heat over a main part of principal edge by distributing the cutting forces. Further, it has been noticed that the change in cutting fluid shows quite dissimilar behavior, means the cutting forces decreases with the change in cutting fluid. Because the viscosity of cutting fluid plays an imperative role to decreases the cutting forces. The Al2O3 based nano-fluids consist high viscosity followed by MoS2 and graphite, means small droplets are formed by using graphite based nano cutting fluids, which results in proper penetration of cutting fluid into the tool-workpiece interface. Also the graphite layered structure and the low friction manners of nano-particles in cutting fluid produce the lower cutting forces (Su et al., 2015).
Tool wear: It can be observed from the perturbation analysis shown in Fig. 3 (b) that, the values of tool wear considerably rises due to the rise in cutting speed along with the feed rate. Whereas it highly decreases with the increase in approach angle and change in cutting fluid. The fundamental explanation behind this occurrence is that, the high Vc and f generates the high cutting temperature and stresses at tool edge. This high cutting temperature and stress at the cutting edge are attached with the brittleness of tool material, which may results in chipping, cracking and fracturing of the tool inserts. Moreover, there is decreasing trend found for tool wear when the cutting fluid changes. This is because of the way that, graphite based nano-fluid have better thermal conductivity as compared to other two fluids. This property of nano-graphite particles helps to improve the heat dissipation of heat through conduction and convection, which retains the hardness of cutting tool for longer times (Sharma et al., 2015). Fig. 4 clearly shows that, there is less tool wear while using graphite based nano-fluids.
Cutting temperature: Fig. 3 (c) exhibits the effect of all machining parameters on cutting temperature. In this work, the cutting temperature at tool-chip interface is highly increasing with the rise in Vc, whereas it slightly rise with the rise in f. The major reason is that, at higher cutting speeds the friction between tool and workpiece increases, which

may result in generation of high temperature at interface. Also, during the turning of titanium and its alloys the heat dissipation is less because of poor thermal conductivity of titanium alloys. But with the increase in approach angle, the heat is spread all over the rake face of tool which results in decreasing of cutting temperature. Furthermore, the cooling action of nano based cutting fluids increases the heat dissipation capacity from the primary cutting zone, which may lead to generation of lower temperature. As expected, the use of nano-particles with MQL lessens the cutting temperature because of their immediate and circuitous cooling impact. The immediate cooling impact was that the cutting fluid with compressed air diverted some of cutting heat by convection heat transfer and the evaporation of cutting fluid at the cutting zone ingested cutting heat. The circuitous cooling impact was to diminish the heat generation by lessening the friction between tool and workpiece (Su et al., 2015). As seen in Fig. 3 (c), the change in cutting fluid decreases the cutting temperature, because the thermal conductivity of nano-particles increases with the change in cutting fluid. Hence the heat carrying capacity of nano-fluid increases with the change in cutting fluid, which results in lower cutting temperature at interface.
Moreover in this study, the microstructure of machined samples was observed as shown in Fig. 5 (a) to Fig.
5 (d). It have been clearly seen that, the change in microstructure greatly affects the machining behavior of titanium (grade-2) under NFMQL conditions. Fig. 5 (a) depicts the coarse microstructure, whereas Fig. 5 (b) to Fig. 5 (d) exhibits the laminar with very coarse grains, which brings about an era of higher shear stresses. Thereby, raising the cutting forces as well as the tool wear while machining of titanium alloys under nano-fluid based MQL condition. Because of the lower thermal conductivity of titanium along with its alloys, the heat developed amid formation of chips can't be efficaciously dissipated into the material nearby the primary shear zone, which results in high temperature values. This high temperature can attain over the transus temperature and may bring about microstructural changes, which results in increase of cutting forces, tool wear and cutting temperature. Also it is observed from the microstructure analysis that, while using graphite based nano-fluids finer laminar structure are produced as compared to other two nano-fluids. The main possible reason is that the heat carrying capacity of graphite is more as compared to other two, which may results in less micro-structural changes. Thus fine laminar structure seems to produce lower cutting temperature, which results in smaller cutting forces and tool wear while using graphite based nano-fluids.
Surface roughness: It is found from the perturbation graphs shown in Fig. 3 (d) that, the value of surface roughness is greatly influenced by the feed rate followed by cutting speed, cutting fluids and approach angle, respectively. The value of surface roughness are mildly increase by increase in cutting speed but it abruptly increases with the increase in feed rate. The main possible reason is that, at high cutting speeds and feed rates large amount of chips flow on the cutting edge of tool causes the high friction, which may lead to high surface roughness values. In addition, this high friction generates the high cutting temperature and changes the physical state of the titanium alloy thus making the surface rough. Moreover, it is a well known basic act that the pitch of surface to be machined is considerbaly
influences by the feed rate (Ra = r f 32
2 ). Further, the high speed-feed combination increases the chatter and vibrations
in machines, which leads to high surface roughness values. However, the surface roughness value decreases with the

increase in approach angle. Because the increase in approach angle, thereby, reduces the tool chip contact length, which promts the low vibration at machine tool, hence surface finisg increases. In the end, the surface roughness values also decrease with the change in cutting fluid from aluminium-oxide based nano-fluid to graphite based nanofluid. This is due to the fact that, graphite based nano-fluids have low viscosity over other two nano-fluids, which are properly settled down between tool and workpiece and provides the cushioning effect, hence leads to low vibration in the machining and increase the surface finishing. Moreover the higher thermal conductivity of graphite based nano-fluids helps to dissipate the heat from primary cutting zone, which leads to lesser tool wear. Lesser tool wear helps in achieving better surface quality by reducing the redeposition of materials on machined surface (Sharma et al., 2015). Fig. 7 depicts that feed marks are clealry visible and clean surface are obtained without any plastic deformation or glazing by the worn tool with predominant feed marks under graphite based nano-fluids as compared to others.

sections.heading: 3.2. Establishment of combined objective
sections.text:
After the complete analysis, the optimization of the input parameters was performed using PSO, BFO and desirability analysis. For this purpose, firstly a normalized combined objective function is generated as given by Eq (11).
Min C.O. = W1 * (CF/CFmin) + W2 * (CT/CTmin) + W3 * (SR/SRmin) + W4 * (TW/TWmin) (11)
Where, W1, W2, W3 and W4 indicate the weightage granted to the various responses as of cutting force (CF), cutting temperature (CT), surface roughness (SR) and tool wear (TW), respectively. The weightages were decided in a manner, so that they together summed up unity (Rao and Kalyankar, 2013). Many random combinations may be tried for finalizing the weightages used in Eq. 11. The individual weights may vary from 0.1 to 0.5, maintaining the summation as unity. But it ultimately depends upon the user. Therefore, one such compromised result is presented in this study where each individual objective is assigned the weightage of 0.25. The combined objective (C.O.)

sections.heading: 3.3. ANOVA test
sections.text:
The analysis of variance (ANOVA) test was carried out on combined objective to identify statistically significant trends. The result of ANOVA for the combined objective is shown in Table 4, respectively. As inferred by this test, if the value of "Prob > F" is less than 0.0500, then the model is significant. In this study, the value of "Prob > F" for developed model is less than 0.0500; henceforth, the model is significant. Moreover, the R-squared values for established model is almost close to 1 and the Adj-R2 and Pred-R2 values shows sensible concurrence with each other.
In Table 4, the F value for the cutting speed is higher than that of the other factors, i.e., the cutting speed contributes the highest portion. Also, the effect of cutting speed, feed rate and cooling condition on combined objective is found to be statistically significant (P-value < 0.05). Cutting speed, feed rate and cooling condition contributed 40.20 %, 36.50% and 20.13%, respectively. The effect of approach angle on combined objective is found to be statistically insignificant (P-value > 0.05).

sections.text:

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The machining performance of titanium (grade-2) alloy under NFMQL conditions was assessed during turning at different conditions. Firstly, the perturbation graphs were used to study the effect of machining paarameters on given responses. Then, the combined objective was developed and the ANOVA was performed to determine the highly significant parameters. Further, the experimental data were optimized through two evolutionary techniques, i.e., PSO and BFO, also compared to the much used desirability technique. Based upon these investigations, the following findings were drawn:
M AN
US CR
IP T

15
1. The performance of evolutionary techniques such as PSO and BFO are far better as compared to the
customary desirability function approach. It is also found that the evolutionary techniques are more effective for determining the optimal machining parameters of titanium (grade-2) alloy considering NFMQL conditions. 2. Lower cutting speed 215 m/min, lower feed rate 0.10 mm/rev, higher approach angle 83° and graphite based
nano-fluids are the optimized conditions to minimize the cutting forces, tool wear, surface roughness and cutting temperature while turning of titanium-II under NFMQL conditions. 3. From ANOVA results, it was found that the effect of cutting speed, feed rate and cooling condition on given
responses are statistically significant. Cutting speed, feed rate and cooling condition contributed 40.20 %, 36.50% and 20.13%, respectively. The effect of approach angle is found to be statistically insignificant. 4. Through perturbation analysis the values of cutting forces, cutting temperatures, tool wears and surface
roughness are increases with the increase in cutting speed and feed rate, whereas it highly decreases with the change in cutting fluid. The effect of approach angle is very less. 5. Also it is observed from the microstructure analysis that, while using graphite based nano-fluids finer laminar
structure are produced as compared to other two nano-fluids. The main possible reason is that the heat carrying capacity of graphite is more as compared to other two, which may results in less micro-structural changes. Thus fine laminar structure seems to produce lower cutting temperature, which results in smaller cutting forces and tool wear while using graphite based nano-fluids.

sections.heading: 5. Future Scope
sections.text: In the category of hard-machining alloys, such as titanium (grade-2) (generally endure low heat transfer coefficient), the approach of Nano-Fluid based Minimum quantity lubrication emerges out as the suitable alternative. However, some parameters like the location and distance of nozzle, geometry of nozzle, percentage concentration of nano particles etc. are still required to be identified in literature. Future work can possibly be extended to other metal cutting operations, like Milling, drilling, and grinding etc. Moreover, as a future scope, different optimization techniques and evolutionary algorithms may be applied for selecting the suitable machining parameters.

sections.heading: Highlights
sections.text:
• Cutting fluids containing three different nano-particles were formulated • Use of three different nano-fluids with MQL (NFMQL) in machining of titanium could not be found in
literature
• The two evolutionary techniques i.e. PSO and BFO are used for optimization • Analysis of variance was also carried out to determine the significant factors for cutting process • Moreover the effect of each parameter with respect cutting force, tool wear, surface roughness and
cutting temperature using perturbation analysis is discussed in this article • SEM has been used to study the structure of machined surface.

metadata.abstractText: In metal cutting operations, the proper selection of machining parameters and cutting fluids affects the cutting mechanism, which is associated to the cutting forces, tool wear, cutting temperature and surface finish of the machined part. For this purpose, the effect of cutting fluid types is investigated as a function of three machining parameters (cutting speed, feed rate and approach angle) on responses (cutting force, cutting temperature, tool wear and surface roughness) while turning titanium alloy under Nano-Fluid based Minimum Quantity Lubrication (NFMQL) environment. The experiments are conducted based on response surface methodology and a combined objective function using the output parameters was generated. Further, the parametric optimization was performed through two evolutionary techniques, i.e., Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Bacterial Foraging Optimization (BFO). The results are analyzed and also compared with the traditional desirability function approach technique.
